name: Pinball Arcade
description: Pinball Arcade by FarSight Studios features exact recreations of the all-time greatest pinball tables from Stern Pinball® and Gottlieb® together in one game. Every flipper, bumper, sound effect, and display pixel has been painstakingly emulated in astonishing detail.

recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: Dual Core 2.0 ghz or better. Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: nVidia GeForce GTX 560 or higher.  ATI HD 6950 or higher. DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 20 GB available space Sound Card: Direct Sound capable card.

reviews.review_text: BIG UPDATE 6/17/2016:  Some idiot at the company decided to upgrade the menu to a sloppy, Valu-soft menu from 1997. If you don't care that the menu is ugly and looks like it was meant for a 640X480 screen, it is now a total pain in the butt to navigate. Before, the tables you owned were separate from the tables you can try and then buy. This was very helpful because there are so many tables to choose from, and being able to click a link to get to your paid content was a time saver. Now every table is jumbled together, and you have to strain your eyes trying to read crappy font and blurry graphics to get to the stuff you paid for. There is no way to sort out your tables. Even if you buy a season pack of tables, and click on the link for your tables by season, you still go to the same screen with all of the tables.  They have also added a new, ugly overlay during gameplay that you have to make sure you get rid of since it adds nothing, but takes away screen space for gray, fuzzy graphics. Remember when the game just told you what ball you were on? Well, now there are stretched .jpgs of a pinball that are of a much lower quality of the table your playing to look at! The best part is that they're not at the sides of the screen either, but at the bottom, making sure that actual table space is being used for useless, ugly graphics.  Oh, and the Star Trek game still isn't fixed.  Essentially, if you want to buy all of the season packs and get all of the tables, this is one of, if not the most, expensive game on steam. You will spend about $100 bucks to get everything, but you won't because many tables are boring on a computer. If you want to buy tables individually, now you're penalized trying to navigate the laziest, ugliest, and most useless menu I have seen since the 90's, and I'm not exaggerating. The graphics, navigation, and color scheme are OLD, and I have no idea why you would update to something so pathetic, and expect to clear $30 to $100 per customer.   When you add in that the game is almost 13gb in size, no joke, this makes Pinball Arcade the stupidest decision you can make by downloading it. Civilization V is 9gb and Gothic 3 is 4gb, and those two games together are the same size as a pinball game? LLLAAAAAAAAAZZZZZZZZZYYYYYY!!!! You have to download every, single pinball machine because they're too lazy to set up a link where you can download the free trial of a machine that looks interesting to you. You're wasting gb's of hard drive space on tables you aren't interested in because the creators are lazy.  Did I mention the Star Trek game is still broken?  Save your money, save your HD space, save your time, and save your eyes, and forget The Pinball Arcade.   OLD REVIEW:  Most of the tables are fine, however most people want to play the Star Trek table, and it's still broken. Everytime I play that table, once I hit over 200 million, there are no more pinballs for me to play with. All you do is hear the music, watch the probes move back and forth, and nothing happens. You can 'call an attendant,' but since no ball is visably stuck on the screen, you're screwed. It's a shame that if you do well on a very popular table, all of your success is wiped out on a glitch.  This problem has been around for years with this table, and other tables if you check around, and I thought someone at Williams ( or whoever is in charge of software quality control ) would try to fix the problem by now. Unfortunately, paying customers have no value once we've paid. Stay away until someone at this company actually starts caring about paying customers.

Don't mind my hours because I've played a ton of Pinball Arcade. I first fell in love with it on the Playstation 3 and eventually moved to the Steam version, which I like much more. I highly recommend getting the season packages. In fact, this is put out by a fairly small outfit with a lot of dedication and passion for pinball, so I pay extra for the pro pack to help support them. I don't even mess with the extra stuff that comes with the pro, except maybe ball skins. They're just worth it.  If you don't know, buying a past season gives you all the games from that season, since they've already released. Your game (Pinball Arcade) updates a few minutes after your purchase, so there isn't an install, unless things have changed since I bought one last. If you buy the current season, there may only be a few games but be patient. Similar to a current season of TV episodes, the games are still being released and you'll get them as they come until the purchased season is over. It gives you something to look forward to!  As an 80s kid, I didn't have money for plunking into pinball or arcade machines. I was one of those who would stand around and watch others play, just to feel the excitement. My father worked in a factory and would sometimes bring home an actual pinball that popped out of a big machine on occasion. I settled for rolling that around on the floor (sad, I know!)  But now, I have more than I could ever dream at my fingertips! And they're so realistic! Farsight takes the actual tables and dissects them, ensuring we get as authentic an experience as possible besides playing the real thing. And while owning real pinball machines sounds great, think of the upkeep and expense, not to mention the room you'd need. It's a romantic thought, but this is way better.  I have a number of pinball video games, but there are two that rule supreme for me: Pinball FX2 (Zen) and Pinball Arcade. I love Zen Pinball for the fantasy angle. They make excellent tables that never existed so anything is possible, especially with Marvel and Star Wars! But when I want to play something that was actually crafted and made the rounds back when I was wishing I could play, that's when Pinball Arcade comes through for me.  I play using a Logitech Gamepad F310, by the way, and it works great!  This is my first time actually sitting down and writing a review here (I think), so I hope it was worth a poop.

Purchasing Farsight Studios' Pinball Arcade packs has been the worst experience I have had in my cumulative experience with buying video games online. Their team completely ignores requests for features they have been receiving for, literally, years... they continue to introduce new bugs to their pinball table packs, and have introduced a new user interface that is so unpopular their overall ratings have dropped from 73% to 44% over the last 30 days (as of the last time I checked).    I won't go into detail on these issues as they are already clearly documented in their user discussions... my intent is to let other consumers know how bad my experience has been buying from this company so that other people can make an informed decision about their purchases. I can assure any interested parties that this developer will not communicate any plan for improvement, bug fixes or for future update timelines, etc etc... they are only interested in selling new content on a monthly basis without any regard for quality or consumer satisfaction whatsoever.  I am lucky enough to have been eligible for refunds on most of the Pinball Arcade content I have purchased.  Thank you for reading... I hope this helps someone to make informed decisions about dealing with this company.

O.K. I've played enough of this game to get a general impression of the quality. I had downloaded it years ago but thought the price of the packs were too high so I uninstalled it. I recently got an urge to play pinball so I purchased Pinball FX2 as it was cheaper and had good reviews. While Pinball FX2 is a good game (I bought about eight tables), I found it a bit gimmicky. I had only played the free Arabian table on Pinball Arcade and thought it was O.K. but it wasn't enough to convince me to spend the bucks to buy a pack. But I did some research and read some reviews and in the end I took the plunge and bought Season Pack One. Boy am I glad I did because it is really good. The authenticity of the tables I find amazing and it has to be as close to playing the real classic pinball tables on a pc as you can get. I found Pinball FX2 to be more flash over substance where as Pinball Arcade is more of a passion of love. I read some reviews complaining about a 'delay' in the flippers but that is all part of the authenticity. On the old pinball machines it was all mechanical so it would seem like a 'delay' anyway because of the moving parts.  As for the price, for the £22.99 or so I paid for pack one, I got about 21 tables so that works out at about a pound per table which is very good value for money. The price may seem high but it is totally worth it. A single table on Pinball FX2 starts at about £1.99 so it is a no-brainer.  I'm just pretty amazed by the realism of the tables - very impressive !  Edit (4/5/2016)  After some more game time I am updating my review. I have now tried out a lot of the tables on Pinball Arcade and whilst they are still very good, my only gripe is that they seem to all be retro tables. I wish there were more modern tables but all the tables seem to be pre-1980's. Anyway, I played Pinball FX2 some more and found a table view I liked and after playing it some more I found it to be more enjoyable than previously thought and not so gimmicky.  So my final conlusion is if you want a retro and realistic pinball simulator with lots of classic tables, than Pinball Arcade is the one to go for, but if you want modern mechanics and tables, then Pinball FX2 is the one to go for.

Have played more of this on Playstation than on Steam, but I am not the owner of that console so I had to pick them up when a good deal came around via Steam. Near-perfect, digital simulations of games from the distant to not-so-distant past that were much more reliant upon your interaction with their 3-dimensional, physical entertainment, is the reason why I nominated this nostalgic collection for the 'Test Of Time' award.

I absolutely love this game, but the recent UI update has completely ♥♥♥♥ed it up. Navigating this new menu is an absolute nightmare. I remember seeing this in beta and it was extremely buggy, so I changed back. Now it's out of beta, and nothing has been fixed? AND we can't go back to the previous UI? What a load of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Even if you can deal with the new UI, imagine how angry you would be if you had a good game going, and then it crashed. Well that's been happening ever since this new update, sometimes the game just gives up and crashes. FarSight, fix this piece of crap.

This is the best pinball game available for professionals, amateurs and just casual couch play. It is outright pinball fun. If you love the game for any reason, this product is fantastic. Grab the free version and play the free content. There's a free table every month and a few free ones included permanently. Pricing is fair, however, as I mention later, the bundling structure leaves a little bit to be desired.  While you cannot substitute the feel of the real machine, you can substitute the strategy involved in playing the games and learning the rules. For tournament players, I can't imagine anything better shy of having to purchase the real tables in order to practice setups. Since this game uses real emulation, all the rules apply as they do on the real tables, therefore developing habits in your gameplay here will translate into the final game. However, only general habits towards the rules of the game.  I never got a chance to play Star Trek: TNG until recently at a Pizza Pub, after I had been playing it for a long time on Pinball Arcade. I was super stoked to find a real table of it. First game on the machine lasted 40 minutes, I scored 4.8billion points and ran through Final Frontier twice. The WHOLE time I was in control and my shots were planned ahead. On a table I'd never played...or did I? My normal first attempt at a new pinball game is flailing my elbows and knees until I slip and hit my chin on the corner and double drain.  Do you transfer the real timing between the digital game and the real table? No. You do not. But did you also know that you don't transfer the timing between the real table and another real table? Some people may think if you return to a real table that you will have developed bad habits digitally or unwisely rely on makeable shots that aren't so much in the real world. This is all true, but real pinball players just know how the real thing is and this disconnect remains a soft barrier as we're not actually the kind of person who truly assumes the digital version WILL replace the real thing in every way. I can't wait until the mode in Pinball Arcade where you gotta scrape out a couple decade old hornet nets.  Timings and tricks are different digitally, that's a certainty, but they're still there because the developers know of them and put them in. Separating yourself from this disconnect between reality and gaming is important in a product like this and if you're one of those people that can do this, you will enjoy this experience a high percentage of the amount you would the real table. If you're one of those people that ♥♥♥♥♥es that the movie sucks compared to the book, then you'll probably have the same knee-jerk reaction. If you really love pinball and you don't own real machines, you have no real other choice if you want to play the real games.  There are some things I'm not fond of:  One thing I cannot let go is a few tables have low enough resolution textures on the general playfield that the text is completely unreadable. ST:TNG is a good example of this when trying to read some of the Quadrant names on the ramp. This is double inexcusable because it isn't even on the playfield, which is a huge surface area requiring the polygons to be broken up all over the place to accommodate the lights and different patches of art. Unfortunately I'm talking about something the developers didn't appear to have thought about doing at all. Rather I think they just added one 2k material to the whole field. It's fuzzy. It's ugly. It's not acceptable for a real commercial product. Luckily, it holds up from a distance mostly, doesn't impede gameplay heavily, and only shows up on table exploration. I still believe this is a super simple thing to have gotten right in the first placem, having been a developer myself for a decade now.  It's not all roses after that though, this is a fair review after all. Another thing I'm not too fond of is the game's current pricing structure. $5 a table is more than fair and never will be unfair, however, as a frugal gamer I like to look for bundle packages. This game offers several bundles in the form of pairs of tables, single tables or entire seasons. My gripe is that the seaons are broken apart based upon when the tables were added to Pinball Arcade, not when that table design was released to the public, by theme or any other factor. Farsight's release schedule making any kind of impact on which tables I can bundle together is a lazy move, if not just stubborn, pointless and irritating. $5 a table and $40 for 15-20 is a good deal. However, I didn't pay that for any season other than season 1, because it had the majority of the real tables I was familiar with. I made the decision based on the ratio of tables I knew and wanted to play again. There's at least 10 other tables in the game I played in the arcades and want to purchase, but I'm not buying all the seasons and I'm not paying $5 each too often. I'm not buying anything more than one table every 3 months until I can pay $40 and choose my own 20 tables my own damn self. Stubborn, I know.   I get the seaons thing, I do. It's cute and I'm glad you guys can share in that in the Farsight Offices. We the people could give a $h!t. You're forcing me to buy stuff I don't want to buy in order to buy stuff I do want to buy. This is somewhat standard in the rest of the world, but making me buy 8 things I don't want to get the 2 I do is a ratio I'm not downs with. You can't guess which ones I want. So why are you making an assumption? Kill the seasons and put a personazable bundle system together within the game itself that ties to your website.  I buy directly from within the game in hopes you don't lose a cut to steam.  Pros: 40,000% savings over a real pinball machine per table Accurate visual representation of the real playfields Real board emulation. If it broke here, it broke there too Great Lighting and rendering. Glass is clean and metals shine Good performance, quick loading Fairly fun activities in the form of challenges and goals No table maintenance QUICK TO RESTART A GAME!!!  Cons: Not the real thing Slightly unstable physics under stress (balls pass through rarely) Some tables have buggy cameras Some tables have low resolution playfield textures No global tournament settings Unflexible bundle offers No table maintenance

I stream pinball on twitch and thus far Pinball Arcade is not only the best because it features greatest hit games from the past, but moreover that they have truly mastered the quirks and physics of the actual machines themselves in a digital form. I can't say enough good stuff about this series. $40 may seem steep pricewise for a season, but if you truly play alot the savings is immediatly evident as pinball standups cost between 1 and 2 dollars per play now. So yeah, if you are into pinball, this franchise cannot be missed in my opinion.

I recommend & don't recommend. Why? Simple. I bought a few tables from off the Mobile version. You cannot transfer them over to the PC version. That means you have to spend $5 each again on the tables you bought or $30 again for the seasons you purchase. So if you plan on playing this on your mobile app, do not bother with the PC/Steam version unless you have EXTREMELY deep pockets. Cause the prices on this game are highway robbery.  HOWEVER, if you take advantage of Steam sales (like right now) you can afford the season packs. (most of them anyway.) Even if you have to reinstall Windows, the tables will always remain on your Steam account.  Also fyi, if you change phones for any reason, you also lose your tables & have to rebuy your tables again. Which is completely unfair, terrible business practice.  So if you're carrying the mobile version around, pay for tables you play often. Best advice I can give.  Otherwise this has to be the best Pinball simulation I played to date. Beautiful graphics and sound. Just be wary that this is very very expensive.

Impeccable renderings of the pinball tables I remember from the arcades of yesteryear. Almost flawless recreations and execution of these wonderful machines. Pinball Arcade has a wonderfully accurate reproduction of the phyics and gameplay. The best I've ever seen in any digitized version of pinball. Almost unbelievable considering the fact that they are created from existing machines and I can't really tell the difference in play from their live versions. Fantastic job.
Very solid game so far. Gave it a test run since it's getting a Doctor Who tabble soon. Can't wait!

Single-handedly reinvigorated my love of pinball. I used to play a whole bunch of these tables when arcades were still a thing. Yes, I'm old. Shut up.   I know some people complain that it's not the same thing, and I agree. It's never going to be an exact 100% recreation. It's never going to be like plunking a quarter into Whirlwind. You know what? I'm fine with that because it's a damn good representation. If nothing else, having things like the instructions really has upped my game. When I play IRL pinball, I'm way better.   One problem might be the price, for some people. Pinball Arcade is not cheap. I started playing it on my PS3, bought three seasons and then realized I'd have to re-buy the same tables when I migrated to Steam. Thank god for sales. I can't particularly complain because the people who make these tables are talented, but it could be a sticking point for some. If you like pinball, though, it's a must buy.

A respectful recreation of classic pinball tables from the companies that made pinball history (Bally, Stern, Gottlieb, Williams). A little rough around the edges in terms of graphics and presentation, but it offers what it promises.
Best pinball simulation simulation out there! It's worth every penny!

Nothing is quite so exciting as a good game of Pinball, and Farsight are doing something wonderful for the world by creating the software version of real pinball tables, so we can all play them. And of course these tables never break down or wear out - they're always in perfect playing condition.
Great game just don't play for long amounts of time or it gets boring rather quick

The PC version is the best TPA for sounds and table art. The console versions sound is crappy most notible is High-Speed my PS4 versions when it does the bonus after just a short while the sound for the bonus just ends and it goes silent. With the PC version it is more true to the real thing.  I should know I own High-Speed here.  The Pros: Great visuals and sound. Play the tables on here then look for them out in the wild!  The Cons: Nothing beats the real thing you do not get the feel of the table and the mechs working and the feel of the ball while it zips around. Ball is pretty much glued to the playfield. No ball hopping like in a real machine which I love! And I noticed unlike the console versions the PC version only has the Season Packs for sale and not individual which is a bummer.

My biggest issue is the price of the tables. I think the 'first two seasons' have the best value because it gets you the most tables per cost, but the later seasons where you get 10 tables for 30 dollars is pretty steep for a game like this.   That being said, I do like the mechanics, it is most 'true to life' pinball available IMO. However, the biggest issue I run into actually playing the tables is their is little to no 'inperfections' on the board. So balls will always 'roll' perfectly and smoothly across. Which makes the game good and bad. Bad in a sense, that when you play the same table IRL and then on the game you could have a wildly different experience, but good, in that you can get a lot of practice on tables and know how you should approach games when you play them in tournaments or at the arcades.   I know some people don't like the UI. I can relate, but to me it's fine. The historical low on DLC has been 14.99 a pack, two months ago they were on sale for around 20 a pack. Which is where I think the price of these should be. I would wait for a sale and get a 'Season or two' of Pinball arcade and it gets a lot funner IMO.   I personally wouldn't waste time getting the pro tables unless you really need options like turning off Extra ball (like they do in pro pinball events.) Otherwise you'll just want to play the games 'stock.'   Overall, I do recommend this game. It's the only option on the market that has real life pinball table emulated as well as they could be.

I love this game. The tables are very detailed and fun to play. The new interface is indeed a bit confusing, but I think it helps you to find your favourite tables faster, if you got a lot of it. You can e.g. sort by your own rating, A-Z or goals you already reached.  My main con ist that the seasons are very expensive. You may say approx 30 Euros for 10 tables - that's 3 Euro each and the devs want to earn money to live. O.K.. But why not make single tables for 3 or 2.5 each? I'd rather spent some money now and then on a few tables I pick myself, than 30 Euros on 10 which of 5 are not that enjoyable...

Simply the best pinball sim I've played. Finally a game that let's you play the REAL classic tables, faithfully recreated in high quality. I don't like that they only offer one table 'free 2 play', but at least it is a great one (Tales of the Arabian Nights). Every table comes with a short overview of its history and you can check out the original advertisement flyer and the detailed ruleset in the table menu. There's custom balls to get, the pro versions of the tables let you even tinker around with the operator menus. The tables are pricey, but they're totally worth it. You can try each one as often as you like until you hit a certain score, finding tables that you like to buy. Pinball lovers should go for this.

I grew up in the era of fading arcades, and one of the things that i grew to enjoy was the wide array of different tables available with all the bells and whistles. it took visual pinball to show me that the older tables were just as good. Pinball arcade is the next evoluton needed to preserve the old classics and the more recent gems. are the season packs pricey? Depends on how you look at them. we could easily be paying for each individual table at a time. as they stand season packs do add another thing and that is a chance to try a table that you never would consider before. I do plan to get season six in the near future, just for two tables alone.

Want the closest thing to the real game of pinball? Look no further. I personally own four of these real games in the library and I can tell you, it's as close as it gets to shaking a machine to keep a ball from going down the side lanes. If you haven't played these games in real life, I can tell you it helps you learn the shots, if anything. Worth a buy along with the season packs. You won't be sorry.

I've played on a lot of purely software pinball games over the years and they cannot hold a light to the original arcade machines. They are either too bland or just don't 'feel' like a proper pinball and lack depth of goals and features.  With 'Pinball Arcade' we have those original arcade machines realised in full detail to take you back to, or introduce you to, those great original full featured tables that used to be in every Arcade all over the world. Over the past few years the developers have recreated an impressive catalogue of classic machines and the choice is vast.  If you were into pinballs at all you are bound to find a few favourites in here to take you back. The physics are excellent, the sound of each table is utterly authentic and the tables have nice crisp graphics. This is THE pinball sim for anyone seeking out an authentic pinball experience. I also have this on my ipad mini 2 and thats the version I play the most...

This is over six GIGABYTES worth of pinball.  You get one table/level for free, but every one of the tables in this thing is the most accurate possible recreation of an actual pinball table that was sold at some point. If you remember a pinball table from your childhood, there's a chance it's in here somewhere. You can play each of the other tables once-ish for free, and after that it's a set price to unlock one permanently.  If you like pinball as much as most people like football, this is the pinball game for you.  The free table isn't bad, though pretty hectic.

I've probably played every Pinball game in existence on various systems but to me 'The Pinball Arcade' is easily the best of them all. No need for Gimmics or Special FX it's as close as you can get without playing the actual Pinball table. Although come to think of it sometimes it's better because there's no dodgy flipper or bad reflections as many Arcades place the tables (in the UK at least) too close to a window.  The DX11 version is the Mutts Nutts (or DB if you prefer !) and with season 5 upon us there are now over 40 tables available. Sure there are a few crap one's but with 3 of my all time arcade favourites in Fish Tales, The Getaway High Speed 2 & Funhouse faithfully reproduced I can't really complain.  The interface is getting a bit clunky now with the number of tables available as you have to scroll through a long list to find the table of your choice. Perhaps a future update will address this with search options or being able to arrange the tables by say season, year or manufacturer as well as a favourites option. When the disc versions of Pinball Arcade  Hall of Fame came out on PS2 & Wii all the tables were represented in an Arcade with so many tables in each room which worked well so something along those lines would be good as well. My only real gripe is the Pro version of the tables which is just a rip off. Why not make them available for free if you achieve all the wizard goals on a table ?.   Above all it's so much fun to play and although I'm a seasoned player I still get frustrated when a ball drains unexpectedly or I tilt the table just short of my all time high score !. But that's what it's all about realistic gameplay that draws you in to having another go. I'm sure you won't regret buying it but I would wait for a sale before buying the earlier seasons. Who know you may get as good as me with lots of practice but I doubt it ! :).
would love to play space invaders silverball mania and medusa on this platform
And the winner of the 'Make a UI like a CD-ROM game from the '90s' goes to... FairSight!  Congratulations!  Here's your grand price.

Don't bother getting this game if you want something free. It's fun if you want to buy it, but it is not 'free' as the game states. Their definition of 'free' means you play a table one single time then get nerved into buying it until you finally find the escape button to get out of the game.

Pinball is a nostalgic thing for many, having been a mainstay in restaurants and arcades over the decades. While they may be mostly a rarity physically for the average person, the Pinball Arcade brings back the classics (and a few modern tables) in a fairly accurate, fun game. I've sunk hours into this game, yet could sink dozens more with just how much fun I'm having. 9/10 game for me.

this pinball simualtion is as close you can come to playing the real pinball without having the real game in your house. I've tried all the emulators witch require you to find the roms witch is an gray area to start with. This by far is the closest and best. There whole process is to take the real pinball and break down the game to it core pieces . Scan them into there software and add there phycics engine.
The closest I'll ever come to acheiving my childhood dream of having dozens of classic pinball tables in my garage that are all set to 'Free Play'.
Despite the absolutely HORRENDOUS new UI, I still love you Pinball Arcade. Just a little less.

The Pinball Arcade is without any doubt, some of the best virtual pinball I've played. From it's fluid and realistic ball physics to the attention to details given to the large selection of tables available, it's easy to see why this latest Farsight release as been so highly praised. A collection of some of pinball's most famous tables are at your fingertips, and you're spoilt for choice with legendary tables such as Star Trek The Next Generation, Black Hole, Terminator 2, Bride of Pin-Bot and Theatre of Magic to name just a few. Plus there's the added bonus of the fact that you can experience the Tales of the Arabian Nights table absolutely free of charge.   Yes there are other pinball games available, but no other features tables based on their actual real life counterpart and none even come close to being able to match how it plays a game of Pinball. There are improvements that need to be made, but you really can't go wrong with giving this one a try. If you a pinball fan, it's a must play.

A great game. I grew tired of waiting for new tables to show up on XBOX360 so bought a new pack here. Once I set up the keys for better play, its almost as good with a controler. Looking forward to getting a xbox to pc controller reciever then its hard to imagine putting any more on my 360 since my PC account will follow my machine where my 360 won't transfer (or so it seems) to xbox one.

The best pinball game in the market, even if the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are spinning off Stern tables to be a seperate game. Not perfect graphically speaking, some of the table scans are really poor and the models could have been better. its too optimized for portable support.  Ive had random bugs in the past about tables going into an impossible state, even with the builtin table reset function.   DX11 executable is a must. The pricing system is lame, particularly for the small amount of functionality added into the pro packs. I love pinball, so i give them my money. If there was another contender on the market , (aside from pinmame + visual pinball setups) , i might persue it.
The best electronic pinball available.
This game has some pretty high-quality simulations of real pinball tables.

The biggest flaw are the horrible floaty physics that don't feel like pinball at all, Balls passing through obstacles. The Web and Timeshock, which came out in 1995 and 1997 respectively, actually felt like a real table.  Ugly menu that's up in your face all the time. Want to play a two player game? This review covers Black Hole, Ripley's Believe It or Not, Tales of the Arabian Nights and Theatre of Magic. I will edit the review if and when I buy and play more tables.  The pinball physics engine is really good for the most part. There are some noticeable ball speed issues where they seem to move at unrealistically fast speeds in comparison to real-life pinball machines. Depending on the table, there are some major differences between the quality of the textures and sounds, but it's usually acceptable. The worst textures are of the flooring and walls, but those can't really be considered as being parts of the tables. It would be nice if the developers actually made an effort to polish every facet of the game though, since the flooring and walls are also part of the gaming experience. At the time of this writing we are waiting on an apparently big DirectX 11 patch, but there's no telling if the overall look and presentation will actually be improved or if more negative aspects will be erroneously added because of the update. Let's hope it's a positive change.  Some tables seem to be plagued by various bugs. I'm not sure if these bugs are also present in the real-life machines, but in Ripley's Believe It or Not, there are some game breaking bugs. Balls will get stuck and the game engine doesn't recognize some key moments, and these bugs will make you stuck. The only way to fix it is to quit the game and go back. I've contacted support about these bugs and they said that they are aware of these bugs and are working on fixes at the time of this writing.  All four tables I played seem to be emulated well, despite the issues I've mentioned earlier. What's great about Pinball Arcade is that all tables available are based on actual real-life machines. You won't find any digital pinball related gimmicks or gameplay mechanics. This game is almost like an unlimited, interactive museum of these classic gaming machines where physics, reflexes, and skills are all that matter. On the other hand, in addition to the lack of overall polish and some bugs, my other complaint is about their pricing model. I understand some people may feel that $30 per pack is reasonable, but I feel that it's a mistake. If the prices were lower and if there were good sales, I'm sure they would sell much more on Steam. It also seems like the Steam/PC platform is not their priority, as they appear to be spending much more time with other platforms. Overall, if you have an interest in playing real-life pinball machines on your PC, this is probably one of the best options available, and new tables are supposed to be added on a monthly basis. This is a great game for people who love pinball.   I've toyed around with the idea of buying a pinball machine for the house. I struggled with several things: where would I put it, which one would I get, how would I maintain it, how much would it set me back. None of those questions came with easy answers. Pinball arcade is at worst a fair compromise and likely a better choice. I can play all the games I enjoy without all the issues owning a real table would bring. For one, my wife will never get annoyed with how Pinball Arcade looks in the house.  Pinball Arcade feels pretty real. The controls on the keyboard do seem to play a little differently than a real Pinball table--slight hesitation from pressing and releasing the flippers, but this very slight. I notice this when I try to pass the ball from one flipper to the other. It's a reflex I developed on real tables and it doesn't quite work on Pinball Arcade. I've read that the game reacts better to game controllers, however I haven't been able to configure it to work with my game pad yet.   The things I really appreciate are the detail in the tables and the sounds of the games. Some of it is pure nostalgia. The tables offered are some of the best available. If they could get Fish Tales and Addams Family that would be awesome.  The physics of the game are great, however they do take a toll on my PC. I've noticed that if I put the anti-aliasing up to 16X and turn ball reflection on high at full resolution that the game will slow down in multi-ball. With those options disabled, the game keeps a steady frame rate.  I've seen a lot of negative feedback about how the game is free to download with one excellent pinball table, Tales of the Arabian Nights. That seems like a very fair model to me. I'd prefer that the tables be offered as regular DLC, but buying them in game isn't that bad.  I'm not sure why people are upset that they get to play a table for free and are asked to pay money if they want more. If they don't like it they're out the free that they paid.  In conclusion, buy if you are a pinball fan. I trust the developers will continue to improve the very minor issues in the game.

I’ve never had such a split feeling on a game before. As a set of pinball tables, Pinball Arcade is phenomenal but as a piece of software, it’s a complete mess.  Pinball Arcade’s main competition on steam is Pinball FX2 (AKA Zen Pinball). Both games strive for something different- FX2 is impossible fantasy pinball whereas Pinball Arcade emulates real critically acclaimed tables. Both are equally valid but I definitely prefer the ‘realistic’ take; part of pinball’s appeal to me is the physicality of the mechanics involved. Arcade’s tables were all hand-crafted and manufactured, meaning they’re generally more carefully designed than FX2’s pure-fantasy offerings. Your own preference may differ but its why Arcade and FX2 are the dominant pinball games on steam without competing directly with one another.  The tables in Pinball Arcade are very diverse and you’ll likely find yourself cherry-picking a few favourites you keep coming back to. Acknowledging that I am still a novice player, my favourite tables so far include The Creature From the Black Lagoon, Black Knight 2000, Junkyard, Star Trek: The Next Generation, Funhouse and Taxi. I was very lucky that my favourite tables happened to fall into Seasons 1 and 3 (I have since also purchased Seasons 2 and 4). The tables are pricey although this is forgivable given the overwhelming amount of licencing agreements required (The Addams Family was particularly gruesome in this regard). I would not recommend buying the tables individually. The number of tables in a season is roughly the same as you’d find in an older disc-based pinball compilation for consoles. Even if a season contains a few duds you don’t enjoy, they typically should each offer a decent variety to make the price worthwhile. There does however seem to be a lack of balance between seasons even though they all cost the same. I also don’t recommend the pro versions unless you’re a pinball-superfan. (On a really bizarre note- at the time of writing seasons 1-4 are on sale with the pro versions costing *less* than their regular counterparts).  The most crippling aspect of The Pinball Arcade is the software holding these brilliant pinball tables together. The interface is horrendous. Previous versions of Pinball Arcade I’ve seen on YouTube presented all of the tables in a large list you’d just scroll through, one table at a time. This is fine for maybe the first season or two but when you have 30+ pinball tables the devs quite rightly decided this interface needed to change. Unfortunately, while the new interface is an improvement in principle- it barely functions at all. Its heavily reliant on the mouse and seems to randomly decide if it wants to recognise your controller d-pad inputs or not. I’ve had to create a steam controller profile just so I can comfortably navigate the menus without having to reach for my mouse. Even this solution doesn’t let me adjust the light sliders for some unknown reason. As well as the unpredictable interface I also frequently lose high scores (the entire driving force of playing pinball), goals I’ve completed and even the list of my favourite tables. The only thing that stopped me from just uninstalling the game after losing my original set of scores is that my top score on each table was still saved on my  pinballarcade.com  profile (also the scores weren’t exactly exceptional in the grand scheme of all players). I believe this is related to steam cloud saves so beware when playing this game on a new machine. Pinball FX2 has none of these issues and if I didn’t prefer the tables of Arcade, it would definitively be the superior pinball game on steam.  Its also not a good idea to have music with lyrics for your video game menu. I used to like Pinball Wizard but I now loathe it based on the sheer number of times I've had to listen to its opening lyrics in Pinball Arcade.  The one saving grace is that I’ve never had Pinball Arcade outright crash on me, otherwise this would have gotten the dreaded thumbs down. Perhaps I should give this a thumbs down to encourage the devs to get their act together but the ultimate truth is that Pinball Arcade is still extremely addictive and in a class of its own so I can only hope the devs fix the numerous issues and make this a more comfortable recommendation.
